div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JULY 31, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

MONDAY, JULY 31, 1905.

Admiral Togo’s offiCial report of the Battle of the Sea of Japan, which appeared in the “Times” of the 24th inst., is the first clear description of the greatest modern sea battle. It contradicts some of the versions of the tactics employed in the fight to which naval experts have given currency in our magazines, and enables the reader to form a juster conclusion than has hitherto been possible of the relative importance of the gun and torpedo and of the value of the tactical formations employed. In the opening paragraphs of the report Admiral Togo points out that in spite of the fog the activity of the Japanese scouts and their free use of wireless telegraphy made “all the condi- tions of the enemy as dear to us who were 30 or 40 miles distant as though they had been under our very eyes. Long before we came in sight of him we knew that his fighting force comprised the Second and Third Squa- drons, that he had 7 special service ships with him, that he was marshalled in two columns line ahead, that his special service vessels followed in the rear, that his speed was about 12 knots, and that he was still advancing to the North Bast.” The ver- sions of correspondents who stated that the Baltic Fleet was formed in three parallel columns, one of cruisers, one of steamships, and one of ironclads, do not seem to be justified by the facts. The right column consisted of the four ships of the Borodino class, the left

was led by the Osliabys, followed by Folker sam’s remaining ironclads and Niebogatoff’s squadron. Between the columns were the Jem tchug and Izumrud, acting as scouts, the cruisers under Enquist formed another squad ron in the rear, and a long way south were the steamships, with the Donskoi and Monomach to guard them, in a long column in line ahead.

At 2.5 p.m., after the famous signal had been hoisted, Togo’s battleship division steamed diagonally from N.W. to 8.E. on the heads of the Russian columns, the Kamimura—armour ed cruiser—division continuing Togo’s line— i.e., fighting in the line with the battleships. At 6,000 yards the Japanese opened fire, con- centrating on the leaders. Rodjestvensky bore away S E. and his two oolumns now formed an irregular line ahead and moved parallel with the enemy. The Osliabya quiokly left the line, Kamimura and Togo closed rapidly, and the Kniaz Suvoroff and the Alexander III. followed the Osliabya, while on the Japanese side the Asama, having her steering gear wrecked and three heavy shells between wind and water, had also to steam away to repair. By 3 p.m. the Japanese were ahead of the Russian line, still moving S.E, and at this point the Russian Admiral suddenly headed N. and attempted to break past the Japanese rear. But Togo and Kamimura’s squadrons wheeled to port and steamed N. W., the armoured oruiser Nishin, which had hitherto been the rear ship of Togo’s division, now lead- ing. Again the Russians were headed off and once more were driven to the E. The Osliabya sank, other vessels were disabled, and the cruiser Jemtchug, which endeavoured to a diversion, was punished for her temerity. At 3.40 p.m. and at 4.45 p.m. torpedo-boat des- troyers and the scout Chihaya made attacks on the damaged Suvoroff. The first attack failed, at the second a torpedo got home, and the ironclad listed to port. At 4.40 the Russian ships turned southward and were lost to sight in the smoke and fog. They seem to have lost their way — four, including one or two coast defence ships, running into the Japanese cruiser divisions that were engaged with Enquist, while the rest turn- ed north again. Togo lost them for a time, and realising the danger to his cruisers, detached Kamimura to aid them in the south, and then went back on his tracks with his own division. Shortly before 6 p.m. be came up on the luck- less Ural (ex Kaiserin Maria-Teresa of the N.D.L.): “the squadron fired once into her and sank her.” At 6 p.m. he was once more in touch with six Russian ironclads steaming N.W. and keeping up with them he hammered them till nightfall. The Alexander III. and Borodino left the line and sank, apparently from gunfire, for Togo does not mention the use of torpe- does, though the Borodino may have been struck while sinking, as survivors asserted.

Meantime the protected cruisers had fought. Dewa and Uriu, shortly after 2 p.m., raked the rear of Enquist’s cruiser division and coming up on his starboard (E.) side fought him on a parallel course or, using their speed, smashed the head of his column. The S.S. ships in the rear fall into disorder though they do not seem to have been the object of any special attack, and attempts made by the Aurora and by three destroyers to close- were repulsed. After 4 p.m. two special-ser- vice vessels, the Irtish and Anastasni, were sunk and the divisions of Kataoka and Togo Masamichi, including the Chinyen and the older cruisers, came into action. At this point four Russian ironclads came back from the N. E., and in the struggle that followed Dewa's flagship, the Kasagi, was disabled and Dewa transferred his flag to the Chitose, with which he convoyed her to Aburaya Bay handing over his two other cruisers to Uriu. Uriu’s flagship, the Naniwa, was next disabled by a shell under the water-line and had to leave the fight at 6.10 p.m. for some hours. But at 6.30 p.m. Kamimura arrived and reliev- ed the pressure and the Russians lied north. Togo, Masamiohi, and Kotaoka des- troyed the Kamtchatka and after 7 p.m. engaged the helpless Suvaroff. With one gun left serviceable she fought the Fujimoto torpedo section, which fell on her covered by the cruisers, but two hits sent her to the bottom. Shortly afterwards Togo’s orders arrived to rendez vous at Urleung Island. The Japanese ran N. E. and Enquist, to judge from the Russian account of the battle, ran south-west with three cruisers, and did not stop till he reached Manila. Here is the situation at nightfall on the 27th May. Two Russian battleship divisions are moving N., one iso- lated and watched by the destroyer flotillas attached to Togo’s force, one accompanied by sundry S.S. ships and cruisers some distance to the south and in great disorder, which steadily increases. The Japanese battle squa- dron is between the Russians and Vladivostok, and making for Urleung. Kamimura is on his way to join it, Togo Masamichi, Uriu with two of Dewa’s ships and apparently Kotaoka are moving N. parallel with the Russian rear, and the torpedo flotillas are closing in on the enemy. All is prepared for the final and utter destruction of the remnants of a great fleet, for the driving home of the lesson that in war, if machines count for much, men count for more.

div.head: VLADIVOSTOK BLOCKADED
div.p: Tokio, July 29.
A strong Japanese squadron is blockading: Vladivostok. (Reuter.)
Tokio, July 29.
A Japanese squadron is blockading Vladivostok. (Havas.)
Tokio, July 30.

The Japanese are steadily overrunning Saghalien and dislodging the Russians from the successive positions taken up by them. They drove out the enemy on the 28th inst. with considerable loss from the vicinity of Rykoff, and captured the town after some sharp but confused street fighting. Subsequently they encountered 800 Russians to the south of that town, killed 200 men and captured 500. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN CENSORSHIP.
div.p: St. Petersburg, July 29.

The censorship throughout Russia is becoming increasingly stringent. Many suspensions have been ordered in connection with the reform agitation. The leading newspaper, the "Novosti,”has been suspended for two months. (Reuter.)

div.head: DISORDERS IN WARSAW.
div.p: Warsaw, July 80.
Strike disorders and murders continue here, The police is completely disorganized. (Reuter.)

div.head: NIJNI NOVGOROD FAIR.
div.p: Nijni Novgorod, July 29.
The great fair was opened yesterday. The town was almost empty and the majority of the shops were shut. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, July 29.
The great fair of Nijni Novgorod is almost deserted. (Havas.)

div.head: GERMANY AND THE BALTIC.
div.p: Berlin, July 29.

The forthcoming cruise of the British Chan- nel Squadron is causing a great outcry here. The Conservative newspapers claim that the Baltic Sea must be regarded as being exclu- sively controlled by the countries bordering it, and Sweden, Denmark, and Russia being un- able to say much, Germany must be considered the mistress of that sea. (Reuter.)

div.head: SWEDEN AND NORWAY.
div.p: Christiania, July 29.
The Storthing has unanimously adopted the Swedish proposals regarding the plebiscite. (Reuter.)
Christiania, July 29.
The Storthing has decided that the plebiscite on the question of disunion with Sweden shall take place on the 13th August next. (Havas.)

div.head: GENERAL ELECTION PROSPECTS.

p.hi: LIKELY TO TAKE PLACE IN AUTUMN.

div.p: London, July 30.
There is a growing belief that the General Election will take place in the Autumn. The Scottish Conservative candidates have been officially warned to be ready before the end of October. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE HELLENIC MINISTRY.
div.p: Athens, July 30.
M. Boudouris has been appointed Minister of War and M. Delyannis Minister of Marine (Havas.)

div.head: ZIONIST CONGRESS.
div.p: AIMS IN PALESTINE
Basel, July 30.

After a stormy discussion the Zionist Con- gress held here has rejected the offer of terri- tory in Uganda and resolved to ask the British Government to use its influence to promote Zionist aims in Palestine. (Reuter.)

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: London, July 29.
Australians beat Surrey by 22 runs. Sussex beat Hampshire by 6 wickets. Leicestershire beat Derbyshire by 87 runs. Essex beat Middle- sex by 7 wickets. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BORGO INTERVIEW.
div.p: St. Petersburg, July 30. In the Borgo interview the Emperor William is said to have advised the Tsar to continue the war, guaranteeing him the maintenance of peace in Europe and premising him financial aid. (Havas.)

div.head: THE TSAR AND PEACE.
div.p: St. Petersburg, July 30.
The Tsar, in replying to a petition urging him not to conclude a shameful peace, says :— "The Russian people may rely on me that I will never make a dishonorable or an unworthy peace.” {Reuter.)

div.head: JAPS NOT OPPOSED TO ARMISTICE.
div.p: New York, July 29.
Mr. Sato, during an interview, stated that Japan was perfectly willing to agree to an armistice after the credentials of the plenipotentiaries had been examined. (Reuter.)

div.head: GENERAL STOESSEL.
div.p: St. Petersburg, June 3O.
General Stoessel has been relieved of the command of the Siberian Corps. (Havas.)

div.head: THE KAISER GOES TO DENMARK.
div.p: Dantzig, July 30.
The Emperor William has left for Copenhagen. (Havas.)

div.head: THE “ENTENTE CORDIALE.’
div.p: London, July 29.

The whole programme for the entertainment of the French officers in August is most elabor- ate and comprises Royal luncheons at Cowes and Windsor. The luncheon at the Guildhall is the culmination of that in Westminster Hall, which is regarded as quite an exceptional com- pliment. (Reuter)

div.head: YELLOW FEVER IN NEW ORLEANS.
div.p: New Orleans, July 29.
Numerous cases of yellow fever have taken place here. The illness is spreading to other cities. (Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Cyprus Journal for July contains a large amount of interesting matter, mainly pertaining to agriculture.
Rotations.—The rotations now enforced in the 2nd Circle of Irrigation are published in Saturday’s “Journal Officiel.”
New Telephone Lines.—Seven new lines of telephone are to be erected in the Markaz of Toukh, Galioubieh province.
Murderer Arrested. — The police of the Karmous ki-m Lave arrested a criminal from Assiout who has been “wanted" for some little time on a charge of murder.
Kasr el Aini Hospital.—The examination for admission to the medical school for sick nurses and midwives at Kasr el Aini Hospital will be held on the 8th October.

Theft of Telephone Wire. — The police are in search of some unknown individuals who out and carried away a hundred and fifty yards of telephone wire belonging to the Daira Khassa near Kom el Dik Fort.

Cart Accident.—An Arab boy, while fly- ing a kite near Bab Sidra, was run over by a cart and received severe injuries to the head and neck. The driver has been arrested and the injured lad taken to hospital.

Suez Canal. — 12 vessels passed through the Canal on the 27th inst., of which 9 were British, 1 German, 1 French, 1 Italian. The day’s receipts were frs. 319,373.39, making the total from the let inst. frs. 7,824,263.84.

Sisters Street keeps up its character. A Greek, who was the worse for liquor, took, advantage of a quarrel which occurred between some Arabs and a group of his countrymen yesterday, to stab one of the former in the thigh.

Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Pont de Koubbeh quarter of Cairo daring to-night and at daybreak to-morrow, and in the Boulac quarter to-morrow night and at daylight on Wednesday, will be poisoned by the police.

New Kuttabs.—Our Zagazig Correspondent states that up to now L.E. 6,400 has been col- lected for the new kuttabs that are to be created in Sharkieh province, the Bandar and Markaz of Zagazig subscribing L.E. 1,400 and Fakous Markaz L.E. 1,350.

The Ways of the Turk.—The chief ulema of Tripoli in Syria, Sheikh Mohamed El Raffei, has been pnt nnder arrest and his house searched from top to bottom. The Turkish police, on being asked to explain their conduct, could only say that the sheikh was known to be a friend of the late Grand Mufti of Egypt! We should have thought that such a recom- mendation should have saved him from mole- station, but they order matters otherwise in the Ottoman dominions.

The Plague.—Saturday’s bulletin records four fresh oases (one fatal) and a death in Hospital at Alexandria. The three oases admitted to hospital were (1) an Italian woman living near the Mahmoudieh Canal, (2) the Sudanese servant of a house in Rosetta- street, (3) a native street sweeper of Eyouni. The fatal case was that of another sweeper who was found dead at the Ragheb Pasha esheshes. A case was also reported from Port Said. Yesterday’s bulletin records two fatal cases at Alexandria, the victims being a native carter and a native coffee-house keeper.

Corporation of Western Egypt, Ltd.—The directors have placed orders for farther steam drillers, which will be shipped to Egypt at the earliest possibly date. These steam drillers will be located at' the Corporation’s depot at Farshut on the Nile as a reserve against any possible breakdown on the part of those at present in the Khargeh Oasis. It is the intention of the board to work these latter in double shifts with an extra staff of men so as to obtain maximum results. Spare parts in connection with all drillers are also being provided, in order that the success of the well-boring operations, shortly to bp resumed on a much larger scale, may be completely assured.

div.head: FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY.
div.p: We have received a copy of the proceedings of the general meeting of the Fajyoum Light Railway Company, held at the company's Cairo office on Jane 9 last, Khalid Bey Lontfi being in the chair.

The report of the administrative board was read to the shareholders present. It stated that in spite of several requests by letter the Ministry of Public Works had not yet given its consent to the construction of a line from Bioufi toKiman Far6s. L E. 1,123.646mm.,being the balance left in hand after the payment of oonpons No. 1 and No. 2, had been carried over to the accounts of the ourrent year. The Mixed Court of Appeal had agreed to the demand of the company that expert examina- tion of the various bureaux of the company should be made, but the experts had ceased to Visit the bureaux though their task was still incomplete. The provisional modifications in the passenger tariff had proved so satisfactory both to the public and to the company, that it had been decided to confirm them. The arrangements made for the transport of goods from all the company’s stations to those of the State Railway Administration and vice versa had proved beneficial to the public, if they had not been of great advantage to the company, which had agreed to the demand of the Railway Administration that It should forward goods from its stations to Port Said and El Kantara. During the year dating from March 1, 1904, to February 28, 1905, the general situation of the company was as follows. The condition of the lines and the traffic were satisfactory. An able European engineer had been engaged who had organised the repairing work in the ateliers, and altered and improved the time-table. It had been decided to dispense with the services of Rangabe Bey, ex-director of the company, who would be temporarily replaced by Mo- hamed Effendi Gazim. The company’s receipts showed an increase of L.E. 4,091.166m.m. on the figures of the previous year, while the expenses had only increased by L.E.882.876mm. This rise was entirely due to the increased traffic on the company’s lines. The total profits for the year, after making every deduc- tion, amounted to L.E. 8,546.676m.m. Per- mission was demanded to pay the sum of L.E. 8,143.200mm., the total of the two cou- pons, viz., 5,220 bonds of the 1st and 2nd issue at 16s. the coupon, as follows : coupons No. 3 and No. 4 from 4,500 bonds of the 1st issue and coupons No. 2 and 3 from the 720 bonds of the 2nd issue, the payment to be made as follows : — Coupons No. 3 of the first issue and coupons No. 2 of the second issue, falling due on December 31, 1902, to be paid on July 9, 1905 ; cou- pons No. 4 of the first and coupons No. 3 of the second issue, all of which fall due on December 31, 1903, to be paid off on August 9, 1905, the remainder of the profits to be carried over to the accounts of the current year. This was unanimously agreed to after the balance-sheet, profit and loss ac- count, and auditors’ report had been presented to the general meeting. The report of the acountants was also passed and it was de- cided that the board should appoint acount ants for next year, A. Adib Bey having informed the meeting that he was unable to continue to fill the post. Certain land owners having presented proposals for the extension of the Kalamsha line to Abou Hamad, it was deoided to snbmit these pro- posals to the board and empower it, if it con- sidered these proposals advantageous, to re- port on them and call an extraordinary gene- ral meeting to which the project should be submitted.
The plans for the Esneh Barrage have been completed and approved by the Ministry of Public Works. They will not, however, be published till the end of October, when tenders will be invited.

The Turkish transports Chark and Mecca, with 700 horses and nearly 1,000 troops on board, have passed through the Suez Canal en route for Hodeida. It is stated that the Sultan has ordered an ice-factory and a distilling apparatus to be set up at Hodeida for the benefit of the troops, who suffer terribly from the want of good water and the murderous heat of the fever stricken “Tehama” or coast belt.

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE NOTES.
div.p: ( From our Correspondent ).
Constantinople, July 25.

The telegraphic agencies will have given you full information of the odious attempt against the person of H. I. M. the Sultan. Among the first telegrams received by our Sovereign congratulating him on his escape, was one from the Khedive of Egypt. The Saltan was greatly touched by the telegram, and replied in a warm message of thanks.

There is some talk here of the creation, in the near future, of a branch of the Anglo- Egyptian Bank at Constantinople. Should the project he carried out trade between Egypt and Turkey would gain enormously.
Wassif Pasha left Constantinople for France last week.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).

- Port Said, Monday. The Russian auxiliary cruiser Kuban, one of the vessels which the Russian Admiralty purchased from the Hamburg-Amerika Line, arrived last evening from, the Canal and has lain here all night. She is to sail this evening for Libau. The vessel, which has a crew of 500 men and steams 22 knots, displaces 8,490 tons. She was with the squadron at the Battle of Tsushima and remained some few hours within signalling distance of Rodjestvensky’s battle- ships, using her five 4-7 guns. When the torpedo destroyer flotilla was let loose on what remained of the Russian vessels, the Kuban retreated at full speed and eventually escaped without injury. The Kuban lay in Saigon for the usual period and then proceeded. I understand the case of the Fazilka is the only one of the kind that , has occurred since the Kuban started on her homeward voyage. She does not coal here, though permission to do so has been granted, and has only taken a limited quantity of provisions and water.
Mr. D. A. Cameron is to leave here on Tues- day in the homeward going P. And O. mail steamer and will be replaced by the Vice- Consul during the three months in which he will be on leave.

I hear on excellent authority that Messrs. Dowrie And Co., who are the lessees of the point bearing their name, have been paid an indem- nity for loss of frs. 600,000 by the Canal Com- pany. The piece of land on which their works stood originally belonged to the British Ad- miralty, and the Canal Company, in the harbour widening which is now going on, decided to remove the point to the extent of some 35 metres. To this end they communicated with the Admiralty and I believe a large piece of land behind Navy House has been given them in exchange, thus putting the Canal Company in the position of landlords to Dowrie And Co., —result, this heavy indemnity.

The steamer Newton Hall, having been ordered to tie up close to Kilo. 133 in the Canal, sent tier lines ashore in the usual way. Some form of discussion appears to have taken place with some Arabs who are working on the Canal bank repairs, which terminated in the latter throwing the mooring boatmen into the Canal. The immediate result was that the vessel was unable to tie up, fell across the stream, and went ashore. The ship’s boat was lowered and an officer and boat’s crew from the ship sent to carry the lines to the proper post, but they appear to have received the same treatment. Daring these attempts the vessel managed to get one of her hawsers round her propeller, thus putting a climax to her chapter of misfortunes. She is at present in- capable of movement, but divers will be sent to her to-day and hopes are expressed that she may be able to proceed shortly. The Canal Company are holding an enquiry into the scatter, which is of the utmost gravity, and may, if it occur again, cause a blocking of the traffic. It is by no means the first case of its kind.
Port Said, Sunday, 1 p.m.
The Newton Hall is proceeding all well and will be here to-night.
(From a Correspondent.)

On Thursday last, a most successful small dance was held at Suez on board the E.T.C. cable ship Electra by the captain and officers. The ship’s quarter-deck was the temporary ball room and a most excellent one it made, tastefully decorated with flags of all descrip- tions, the awnings overhead being roofed in with the ensigns of all nations, while electric lights in Chinese lanterns shed a soft and romantic light on the brilliant and cheerful assembly, chief of whom was H. E. the Governor, who was-apparently in the best of spirits and greatly pleased with everything. The deck made an excellent floor and the music was of the best, the hosts being fortunate in preparing the services of Mile Gladulich, who played the piano to perfection, thus greatly adding to the success of the evening. The piano was placed in quite a little bower, viz., on a raised plat- form at the stern draped round with flags and decorated with plants.

The night was perfect for the occasion and Captain Sparks and his officers missed but very few of their friends, who included practically all the English-speaking community of Suez. 2 am. saw the end of one of the most successful small dances ever held on board ship in Suez, the hosts being amply repaid for their trouble and the care taken over the decora- tions,by the enthusiastic admiration expressed on all hands.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Senegal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due at Alexandria to- morrow morning.

The Ellerman S.S. City of Oxford, from Liverpool, Gibraltar, and Malta, arrived here on Friday with general cargo and passengers. The Ellerman S.S. Bulgarian, from Alex- andria, arrived at Liverpool on Thursday.
The Moss liner Rameses sailed from Liverpool on Friday last and is due here about the 11th prox. with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From our Financial Correspondent)
London, July 21.

The past week’s stock markets, although distinctly better in tone, offer little opportunity to your correspondent to write much of inter- est. There continues to be a good demand for investment stocks, and there is certainly a growing feeling of confidence in the hope of a good result of the peace conference, especially as the general opinion is thai this has by no means been discounted here.

The mining section cannot be said to be "out of the wood,’’ for mining securities are being looked at more and more askance by the banks and loans to mining firms are by no means easy to negotiate. This adversely affects the Egypt- ian Mining section,—a treatment it does not deserve. An excellent export of United Afri- cans has followed the good export of the Nile Valley Company. Although the market has certainly improved, it has not responded so readily as it would have done under better general conditions.

Other Egyptian securities are steady, with little doing. Land shares are practically un- changed, and Banks firms, the strongest point being Agricultural Banks at 14, for ransom to which we drew attention last week.

Gilt-edged stocks are quite neglected and Consols have declined 1/8 to 90 1/16 for money and 90 1/8 for the account. The new Japanese loan is offered at 1 premium for the special settlement, the previous issue being quoted at 93. Russians are inclined to be easier.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mgr. Aurelio Briante has returned to Alex- andria from Cairo.
Mr. Malcolm McIlwraith, the Judicial Advi- ser, was invested with the Order of St Michael and St George by H. M. the King at Bucking- ham Palace last Monday.

Mr. Dupuis, Inspector-General of the Sudan Irrigation Service, leaves by the P. and 0. boat to-morrow for a two months’ holiday in England. Mr Dupuis will then proceed to Canada and the USA. on the special mission which has been assigned him, viz., the examin- tion on the spot of the most modern types of dredgers with a view to their employment on the upper waters of the Nile.
Mr. H. Carter Wilson has returned to Cairo and resumed his functions at the Ministry of the Interior.
The leave of Mr. Dunlop, Secretary-General of the Ministry of Public Instruction, has been extended to the 21st August.
Col C. Rawnsley, D.S.O., commanding the Army Service Corps in Egypt, leaves for Cyprus to-morrow in order to hold an inspec- tion there.

Crookshank Pasha, who at present is doing the “cure” at Vittel, near Contrexeville, is due in London on the 4th August for an important meeting of the directors of the Corporation of Western Egypt, and leaves immediately after- wards for a month’s salmon fishing on the Sundal River in Norway.

A marriage has been arranged and will shortly take place between Captain Claude Rome, 11th Hussars, eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Rome, of Charlton House, Charl- ton Kings, Gloucestershire, and Grace, second daughter of Sir James Blyth, Bart, of Blyth- wood, Stansted, Essex, and 33, Portland place,W.

A cable to the "New York Herald’’ (Paris) from New York of last Sunday’s date states:— "Miss Antoinette Sherman, 'daughter of Mrs. Frederick, Sherman, of Paris, was married yes- terday to Georges Gabriel Abdel Messih Bey, of Cairo, at the home of the bride’s uncle, Mr. Charles de Rahm, in Fifth avenue. The bride- groom is a wealthy Persian. The bride is one of the wealthiest American residents of Paris, and well-known in Newport society. The couple will probably reside in Paris.”
We regret to announce the death of Miralai Haasan Bey Sadik, commandant of the Khedi- vial Guard and bandmaster-in-chief, which occurred at Dakma, Menoufieh province, on Thursday.

Since March, 1905, the grave of General Sir Hector MacDonald, in the Dean Cemetery, Edinburgh,has been unmarked. A monument has, however, now been erected by public subscription, and takes the form of an obelisk supported by cannon balls at each corner. In front of the base stands a pedestal with a bronze bust, showing Sir Hector in the uniform of an Aide-de-Camp to the King, displaying his many orders and medals, British and Egyptian.
M. Cortessi, a Greek notable of Cairo has presented 1,000 francs to the Greek Govern- ment for military equipment.

Bien que le ministère de l’Intérieur ait ap prouvé en principe le projet d’accord entre la Municipalité et l'entreprise Ahpagià, il a fait remarquer toutefois qu’une voie Decauville ayant à franchir un passage à niveau sur deux voies de tramways présenterait non seulement un grand inconvénient mais même un danger pour le trafio d’un service aussi fréquenté que le sera le tramway du quai.

Il a ajouté qu’il serait de l’intérêt de la Municipalité d’insister sur ce. point près de l’entreprise Almagià, mais que si cette dernière soulevait des objections, elle devrait accepter tonte la responsabilité des accidents qui pour- raient survenir par suite de l’obstruction tem- poraire de la voie des tramways par ses wagon- nets ou ses matériaux, et qu’elle devrait s’en- gager à placer des gardiens à ses frais à l’en- droit du croisement.

Depuis quelque temps les orgues de barbarie sévissent comme un tléau dans notre ville, déjà si éprouvée par la poussière et le mauvais fono tionnement des égouts. Impossible de jouir d’un moment de tranquillité. Dès que, le soir vena, la population, excédée du labeur de la journée, prend place dans les restaurants ou dans les cafés, les joueurs d’orgue se succèdent sans interruption et lui serinent bon gré mal gré des airs de casserole. Bien ne sert de crier grâce ; ces gens-là n’ont pas de pitié.

Bon nombre d’entre eux, d’ailleurs, sont en état de gagner pins honnêtement leur vie ; certains sont des colosses aux épaisses mous- taches dont le casier judiciaire n’est pas propre et qu’on s’étonne de voir la polioe tolérer dans les rues. Un de oes drôles, hier soir, malgré les protestations de tous les clients, s’installa devant un restaurant en face de la mosquée Attarine. Comme on le priait de se re tirer, il se mit à proférer des menaces et lança contre un groupe, assis à la porte, nn outil de cuivre qui heureusement manqua son bnt.
Nous voulons croire que la police et le con- sulat prendront des mesures nécessaires pour empêcher qu’un colosse aussi dangereux ne continue à terroriser la ville.

Samedi matin une maison en oonstructionau fond de la rue Attarin s’est éoroulée, ensevelis- sant sous ses décombres la femme du proprié- taire. Les murs intérieurs avec leurs couvertures se sont effondrés. Heureusement le reste de l’immeuble n’était pas encore occupé, sans quoi on aurait à déplorer de nombreuses victimes.
Funérailles

Les funérailles du regretté E. D. J. Ddtilh, conservateur du cabinet numismatique ont eu lieu samedi dernier à 5 b. p.m. au milieu d’une fonle innombrable parmi laquelle nous avons remarqué S.E. Fakri Pacha,' régent d’Egypte, M. Am. A. Ralli, viœ-président de la Commission Municipale, M. le Dr Scbiess Bey, président du Comité du Musée, M. L. Stienon, consul des Pays-Bas, M. le Dr Breccia, conservateur du Musée Gréco-Romain d’Alex- andrie, Ahmed Bey Kamal, conservateur ad- joint du Musée du Caire, envoyé spécialement pour représenter la Délégation Générale du Service des Antiquités.

Le char funèbre était précédé de gardes municipaux et du Musée et de quatre magni- fiques couronnes envoyées par la Municipalité d’Alexandrie, le Servioe des Antiquités du Gaire, le Musée d’Alexandrie, et le personnel du Crédit Lyonnais ; il était entouré de MM. A. Ralli, Dr Sohiess Bey, Pachundaki, délégué par S.E. Fakhry Pacha, président de l’Institut Egyptien, et le Dr Breccia.
Le cortège passa par le Boulevard Ramleh, Rue Nabi Daniel et rue Porte Rosette.
Au cimetière, après les prières et les céré- monies d’usage, M. le Dr E. Breccia pro- nonça avec une voix très émue un discours de circonstance.
M. Pachundaki prit ensuite la parole au nom de l’Institut Egyptien et prononça quel- ques mots en l’honneur du regretté défunt.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH CO., LIMITED
div.p: AVIS

Messieurs les porteurs d’obligations de la Daïra Sanieh 4% 1890 revêtues de l’estampille conformément à l’avis des contrôleurs du 31 Août 1904, sont avisés qu’il a été déoidé de procéder le 15 Octobre 1905 au rembourse- ment de leurs titres en espèces au lieu de l’échange contre de nouvelles obligations. Ce remboursement aura lieu aveo la prime men- tionnée par l’avis des contrôleurs et par con- séquent à raison de 525 francs par obligation. En conséquence, les porteurs d’obligations de la Daïra Sanieh estampillées qui n’aurait pas fait usage du droit de souscription privilégié aux obligations foncières 3% à émettre par le Crédit Foncier Egyptien le 25 Juillet courant sont invités à déposer leurs titres au plus tard le 1 Octobre 1905 aux guichets des établisse- ments financiers suivants :—
à Londres chez MM. Stern Brothers

row.cell: la Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas

div.p: Les titres devront être munis du coupon N. 31 à l’échéance du 15 Avril 1906 et des suivants attachés. Le montant de ces coupons dont lee titres ne seraient munis, sera déduit du capital à rembourser. Le oonpon N. 30 à l’échéance du 15 Octobre 1905 ne sera pas payé de la même manière et aux mêmes caisses que les coupons précédemment échus. Les por- teurs seront déohus quinze ans après le 15 Ootobre 1905 de tout droit de réclamer les sommes qui pourraient leur être dues du ohef du remboursement Le remboursement sera effectué à partir du 15 Octobre 1905 au pair augmenté de 25 francs et ce à Paris en francs, à Londres en livres sterling au ohange de 25 franos par livre, à Berlin en Marks an taux dn change oaloulé à la parité de 25 franos par livre sterling.
Après le 1er Décembre 1905 le rembourse- ment n’aura plus lieu qu’au Caire à la Société Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh, ou à la Na- tional Bank of Egypt.

Les articles sas-mentionnés peuvent être exa- minés à Ramlet (Boulao) oü ils sont déposés et d’où l’adjudicataire pourra les enlever, à ses frais, tels quels et en l’état où ils se trouvent H»n« an délai de 30 jonrs de l’aooeptation de son offre (les jonrs fériés exoeptés); faute de quoi, la vente sera annulée et le montant dn cautionnement de plein droit acquis à l’Admi- nistration.
Tout soumissionnaire devra verser, an préa- lable, nn cautionnement provisoire de LE. 15. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire oe dépôt aux 10 % du montant de la vente consentie.
Le cautionnement définitif sera conservé à la Caisse Centrale de l’Administration, non productif d’intérêts josqn’à l’enlèvement com- plet des artioles ad j âgés.
Toute offre faite ou déposée postérieurement à la date et à l’heure sus-indiquées ne sera pas prise en considération.
L’Administration ne s’engage pas à aooepter l’offre la pins élevée, ni à donner suite aux soumissions faites. Elle se réserve en ontre le droit de diviser la vente.

div.head: THE MEGOTTIER.
div.p: In the French metropolis the trade in “megots” (cigar stumps and cigarette ends) continues to be carried on with fluctuating fortune, for the threadbare tribe therein en- gaged. The second-hand tobacco dealer is miserably poor. The cast away remnants of expensive cigars or cheap cigarettes he scrapes together in the streets bring little grist to his mill. Yet all the year round he con- trives to earn his daily bread, if not his cheese, and only in very hard times is he driven to pass the night beneath the arches of the city bridges. The microbist of the period, the scientist, with members of hygienic societies now and again in their comfortable homes or well-appointed committee rooms, expatiate on the expendiency of suppressing the megottier’s industry, which spells danger for the public health, for who knows what germ of disease may not lurk in the neatly- rolled second-hand cigarette clandestinely sold, the State tobacco monopoly not withstanding? As a matter of fact, however, the “megottier” still plods along on his weary rounds, a dilapidated human ruin, on whom privation and misery have set their stamp.

Purchasers of tobacco at second hand, be I it noted, in no way ignore the origin thereof. Between the seller and the buyer there is neither dissimulation nor fraud. Only in the vicinity of the Place Maubert, on the left bank on the Seine, far away from fashionable Paris, can the “megottier” dispose of his wares. Persons in whose slender budgets every penny counts are apt not to be over squeamish. Their name in large cities is legion, and it is among them the collector of castaways finds his market. Years ago the recognised head of second-hand tobacco dealers was a certain Pere Antoine, a brave old soldier decorated with the military medal, who in his declining years took to the megottier’s calling to keep the wolf from the door. Pere Antoine, in due course, went over to the great majority, and since his removal no one has succeeded him as commander-in-chief of the threadbare clan, The “megottier” is as familiar to Parisians as Napoleon’s statue on the Place Vendome. With a touch of his shapeless cap to that imposing gentleman the cafe overseer, the collector of castaways thrusts his pronged stick beneath the terrace tables, dexterously impaling as many stumps or ends as possible, the booty thus obtained being forthwith trans- ferred to a capacious pouch slung across his shoulder. A rich harvest is reaped by a patient exploring tour along the boulevards, but a good deal is also done at the doors of theatres or clubs. The most prosperous season for the cafe business is the summer, when terraces remain crowded far into the night, and cigar and cigarette remnants are not so liable to be spoiled by rain or mud, as in the winter. That season brings a hard and unremunerative time for the poor fellows following the calling, and according to capitalists engaged in the trade, the now general adoption of the cigarette in preference to the cigar by French smokers of the period is also detrimental to their interests. The cigar-stump trade naturally yields the greater profit, since it supplies the sole material for the rough-cut, which is most in request.

The manipulation requisite to transform what may be called the raw material into a marketable product varies according to the season of the year. In winter when a man has collected a sufficient quantity of cast- ways, he goes home and puts them to dry on the floor of his wretched garret. The drying process terminated, the ends of the stumps are carefully removed. The remainder after proper cleansing is cut up on a board into thin shreds to be subsequently drawn out and rubbed between the hands. By this simple process it assumes the normal aspect of lowest smokeable tobacco. This is the rough-cut or the “gross,” the sort most in demand. The fine cut or “fin,” derived from cigarette ends, is merely cleansed. In bright summer weather these little operations are carried out in the open air on the river quays, on the fortifications, or elsewhere, according to circumstances. With newspapers spread out, purveyors of needy smokers prepare their wares, allowing nothing of what the street has yielded to be lost. Even the wetted ends that were put aside are boiled down with soda. The liquid thus obtained is sold to horticulturists as an insect des- troyer, very potent in its effect with a certain class of plants.

The Place Maubert, on the left bank of the Seine, is a locality completely devoid of gen- tility, but precisely for this reason it consti- tutes an excellent retail market for the “megottiere.” The men take up their stand on the kerbstone of the pavement a few yards from the statue of Etienne Dolet. They thus face three or four thoroughfares converging there from the Seine, which constitute the route followed morning and evening by a multitude of city toilers. The salesmen are not sociable. They rarely converse among themselves, standing apart, biding their time and awaiting customers. The Latter have their preferences. While one vendor will speedily get rid of all the packets of tobacco his wallet contains, another, whose aspect, perhaps, is less cleanly, will have to leave the place with very few coppers in his pocket. Very little bargaining goes on at the Place Maubert. Second-hand tobacco is sold at a fixed price—about a quarter or third of what it would cost if purchased in the regular way at the tobacconist’s.

The Paris megottier enjoys an excellent reputation for honesty. In the course of his rambles while scrutinising the pavement it not infrequently happens that he lights upon something more valuable than a cigar stump. Be there something—a jewel dropped by a lady as she is entering a theatre, a gentle man’s diamond shirt-stud, or a dainty lace handkerchief—he will take his find to the Police Commissary. If not claimed within the delay of a year and a day the property belongs lawfully to the finder. Windfalls of the sort aTe occasionally dropped by Dame Fortune into the megottier’s shapeless cap.

div.head: NO POLICE &LITTLE CRIME.
WHY NOT TRY WEH-HAI-WEI AS A HEALTH RESORT?
div.p: Mr. J. H. Stewart Lockhart, the Commis- sioner, in his an annual report on Wei-hai-Wei, says :—“In certain quarters there has been a tendency to scoff’ at Wei-hai-Wei as a place that might be dropped out of the list of British possessions without being much missed. Such criticism seems to forget the progress already made under circumstances not altogether favorable; to ignore the fact that the harbour, which is the best north of Hong Kong, is of great use to our fleet ; and to be unmindful of the value of the climate to a European Power with vast interests in the Far East."

Under the heading of “Medical and Sani- tary,” Mr. Lockhart says:—“The climate, with its delightful sunshine, prevalent throughout the year, and its dry, bracing atmosphere, so fully charged with ozone, is one that appears specially adapted for the home of the con- sumptive patient or the treatment of his disease. Suitable sites, with a southern aspect, and sheltered from the north by high hills, are plentiful, and there seems no reason why a sanatorium for die treatment of consumption should not be successfully established here. In the opinion of cue medical authority, who has lived here, such a sanatorium would ensure a better prospect of cure than in any place in the United Kingdom.”
NO SERIOUS CRIME

The Commissioner remarks that one of the most remarkable features of the government of Wei-hai-Wei is the entire absence—setting aside Liukungtao and Port Edward—of a police force. So far from this resulting in anarchy or lawlessness, it appears to have the opposite tendency, for the territory is excep- tionally free from crime of a serious nature. An obvious comment bright be that the crime exists, but owing to the absence of the proper machinery is not discovered; but this is an erroneous criticism, for the victims of crime rarely fail to bring their complaints to the magistrate, and of the cases that remain, few escape the vigilance of the detective inspector.

Among several reasons which might be given for this satisfactory state of matters, perhaps the most important are the modified patriarchal system under which the vast majority of the people still live and die, and the entire absence of the ferocious clan feuds which are so ugly a characteristic of the southern provinces. The country is too poor to tempt immigrants, and lands seldom change hands except among rela- tives. Farms are often mortgaged, but nearly always subsequently redeemed.
VILLAGES AND ANCESTORS

The villages are generally Darned after fami- lies that have lived in them for many cen- turies. Sun Chia T’an is the village of the Sun family ; Ch’i Chia T’an is the village of the Ch’i family ; and so on with most of the villages in the territory. Title-deeds and tomb- stones all reveal the same tale; the landown- ers are everywhere the direct or collateral descendants of the people who tilled the same fields in the days of the Sung or the Ming dynasty.

A curious result of this is the manner in which individuals identify themselves with their own ancestors. “I bought this land, and now the Liu family are trying to steal it from me,” complains a petitioner. “When did you buy it ?” remarks the magistrate. “In the fourth year of Yung-Cheng,” says the peti- tioner, and sure enough his title-deed bears the date of 1727. Nearly every man has his few acres of arable land and his share in the common pasture land ; every one is respon- sible to someone else for his correct behaviour, and all owe some obedience to the elders of his house it the village headman or ts’un tung.
"WRONG IN THE HEAD"

As compared with the inhabitants of Fuh- kien or Kuangtung provinces, the peasants of Shantung are deplorably ignorant and illiter- ate. Even the headmen are generally unable to read, or have forgotten the few “char- acters” they ever learned, and the village schoolmasters are rarely able to write good classical Chinese. The want of education is accompanied too frequently by an amiable lack of intelligence : amiable, because so smilingly acknowledged. “My husband is wrong in the head,” remarks a female plaintiff who wants to win the magisterial sympathy, “and really I am not munch better myself.”

As is so frequently the case in eastern coun- tries, the children are often far brighter and more intelligent than their parents; and young boys are frequently brought into court to help their elders to explain themselves.

div.head: THE ORKNEYS AS A ROYAL DOT
div.p: The sale by auction of three of the Orkney Islands recalls the fact that the Orkneys and Shetlands remained under the Norwegian do- minion from the time of Harold Harfager till 1468, when they were transferred to Scot- land by a marriage treaty. By the marriage contract between King James III. and Mar- garet, daughter of Christian I., King of Nor- way, Denmark, and Sweden, it was agreed that these islands should remain in the pos- session of King James and his successors as the Princess Margaret’s dower until either King Christian or his successors should pay to King James or his successors the sum of 50,000 florins of the Rhine. In the year following, however, on hearing of his daugh- ter’s delivery of a prince at Edinburgh, Chris- tian, "for joy thereof renounced for ever to the Crown of Scotland all right or claim to the said islands."

div.head: THE STAMBOUL OUTRAGE.
FURTHER DETAILS.
div.p: An official note issued to the Constantinople papers on the subject of the attempt made on the Sultan’s life states that the explosion took place at a distance of about 100 yards from the Hameieh Mosque, at a point where the carriages of the worshippers stand, and behind the position occupied by a regiment of ca- valry. The Sultan, who, at the moment of the explosion, was just coming from the ceremony of the Selamlik, was not in the least perturbed, and, with admirable sangfroid, entered his carriage, acknowledging the con- gratulations of the troops and personages present, and returned to the Palace.
The note adds that the author of the out- rage is being searched for, and various mea- sures have been taken to ensure his capture.

Up to the present not the slightest clue has been obtained either as to the author or the origin of the crime. The authorities are inves- tigating all sorts of conjectures and theories, as, for example, that the criminal was a foreign Anarchist, or, as others think, that the attempt was the work of a Macedonian, Bulgarian, or a revolutionary Armenian, or according to another hypothesis, that it should be attributed to a discontented Arab fanatic, or to the Young Turkish party.

Among those injured by the bomb explosion is a man, apparently a foreigner, who is un- identifiable in Constantinople. The killed include Beha Bey, tutor to the Sultan’s sons, and several soldiers, a police agent, and an aide-de-camp, whose blood-stained uniform was noticed in the corner of the Mosque where Beha Bey was found. The latter’s head had been pierced by a splinter of the bomb. In all, twenty-four persons were killed and fifty- seven wounded. The bulk of the victims were coachmen. Twenty-seven hackney coaches were blown to pieces, and fifty-five horses were killed.

Eye-witnesses state that the scene immedi- ately after the explosion was heartrending. Men and horses lay dying around the large hole, about two yards wide, made in tho earth by the bomb, and pieces of human flesh were found lying a long way off, where they had been thrown by the explosion.

It will probably never be possible to ascer- tain exactly the details of the outrage, as every- body in the immediate vicinity was killed. It is thought, however, that a person was in the act of hurling the bomb as the Sultan emerged from the mosque, when a bystander tried to prevent him, and the bomb fell, exploding in the fall; or that the bomb exploded prema- turely, having been dropped by accident.

It is stated that the authorities some days ago received a warning that an outrage of some sort was being plotted, but no attention was paid to the warning, the nature of which did not seem to imply verisimilitude. Extraordi- nary precautions are being taken by the police, and the Customs officials are carefully search- ing the luggage of all travellers leaving the country, and no carriages are allowed to enter the Court of the Sublime Porte.

div.head: THE BLACK ART.
div.p: Oscar Bonne and Elizabeth Sibbel, calling themselves astrologers and “experts in the black arts,” have been sentenced at Duisborg to three years’ imprisonment for fraud.

The woman Sibbel, who pretended to be in league with Satan, rented rooms which were fantastically upholstered in black and silver, stuffed eats, tortoises, and snakes being scat- tered about everywhere.
Consulting clients were received by her in solemn silence, Sibbel being dressed in long robes of black and red, with an aureole of silver stars decorating her head.

On the payment of fees varing from five shillings to fifty pounds she would burn in- cense at tho feet of a colossal statue of Buddha, which she gave out to be an Eastern representative of her patron the Arch-Fiend.
After pronouncing a sort of incantation, the client heard sounds of singing proceeding from behind the heavy draperies which separated the room from the rest of the apartments.
The singing was supposed to be that of Satan’s choir of demons, who in this way were replying to Sibbel’s questions as to the future destiny of her client.
In reality it was her confederate Bonne, who, possessing a melodious tenor voice, was sing- ing Hungarian love songs in the adjoining room.
Before leaving Sibbel’s consulting-rooms, her clients were anointed with what purported to be mystic unguents, rendering them immune against disease and ill-luck.
For this ointment Sibbel charged from one shilling to £6 each time, the tees varying according to the station of her client.
The preparation, on examination, proved to be a compound of beeswax, vinegar, and rancid lard, and gave off a fetid odour.
She has made, it is estimated, nearly £700 from this traffic alone in various parts of Germany during the last four months.

div.head: THE BACCHUS TRAIN.
div.p: Civilisation advances. “Bacchus specials,” to collect and carry inebriated trippers during Bank and other holidays, are to be run on the Lancashire and Yorkshire Railway. Out of consideration for the sensitive feelings of those who use them, the screens will be kept down, and a "dim religious light” will prevail, in order that mutual recognition may be avoided. A trial trip took place last Saturday week, when sixty rejected patrons from the other trains were deported to their destination.

div.head: PIGMIES AND THEIR SPEECH.
SIR HARRY JOHNSTON’S DISCOVERY.
div.p: “What language do the pigmies speak ?” is a question often asked in regard to the little people from the African forests.

The question is now, I believe, satisfactorily settled (writes a “Daily News” representative), and the answer is that they have no real lan- guage of their own at all, but speak a dialect known locally as “momvu,” which they borrow from the neighbouring tribes in the Ituri forest.

This, at all events, is the conclusion arrived at by Sir Harry Johnston and the committee of which he is chairman. The committee in question was appointed with the express pur- pose of considering the pigmies from philo- logical and other standpoints by the Anthropo- logical Institute of Great Britain and Ireland, and, in addition to Sir Harry Johnston, its members included such authorities as Professor Thomson, Dr. Keith, Dr. Rivers, Dr. Murray Leslie, Professor Gowland (President of the Institute), Mr J. Gray (treasurer), and Mr. T. A. Joyce (secretary). In their interesting investigation the committee have had the assistance of Col. Harrison, who has charge of the little people, and is responsible for their return to their forest homes. The report of their investigation, when it is made public, should prove interesting, as it will cover not only the question of language, but other matters relating to the physique, food, and habits of the pigmies.
The language question has been Sir Harry Johnston’s chief care, and in pursuit of his inquiry he has paid many visits to the pigmies at their lodgings in the vicinity of Tottenham Court-read.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
London, July 20.

Captain W.H.Drake,R.A., the new D.A.A.G. of the Egyptian Army, was lately employed as a staff captain at Khartoum. He is a smart young officer of twelve years’ service, the last two and a half of which have been spent in Egypt.

Captain H. B. Protheroe-Smith, 21st (Em- press of India’s) Lancers, has been selected for duty with the squadron of Military Mount- ed Police in Egypt. This officer was a staff captain in Egypt for some time, so that he is no stranger to the Land of the Pharaohs. He saw service in the Nile Expedition of 1898, including the famous charge of the Lancers at Omdurman. Mentioned in despatches, medal, Khedive’s medal with clasp. In the late South African War he was attached to the Carabiniere, and participated in the Colesberg operations, the actions of Paardeberg and Driefontein, the relief of Kimberley, and he was aide-de-camp to Sir John French after the fall of Pretoria, including the actions of Diamond Hill and Johannesburg (medal with five clasps).

Captain P. F. R. Anley, 1st Battalion Sher- wood Foresters, at Singapore, has been select- ed for service with the Khedive’s Army. Captain Anley joined the Foresters in Decem- ber, 1896, was promoted captain in January, 1901, whilst on active service, was with the 1st Battalion in the Boer War, and participat- ed in the actions of Bethulie Bridge, Winburg, Lindley, Houtnek, Vet River, Zand River, Welkom (very much misnamed), Doorn Kop, Pretoria, and Diamond Hill, and the opera- tions in the Western Transvaal against Delarey and Kemp, including the action of Moedwel (medal with four clasps).

Captain H. C. E. Green, 4th Battalion King’s Royal Rifle Corps, has taken up the duties of aide-de-camp to Major-General Sir Edward Hutton, commanding the Third Division of the Aldershot Army Corps, during the drill season.

Second Lieutenants W. D. Barber and E. G. St. Aubyn, King’s Royal Rifle Corps, serving respectively with the 1st Battalion Northern Nigeria Regiment and the 4th Battalion of the Rifles at Gosport, have been promoted lieute- nants, after four years and three months’ ser- vice. Both officers served in the late Boer War.
Second Lieutenant E. T. W. M’Causland, Royal Berkshire Regiment, has been transferred from the 1st Battalion at Dublin to the 2nd Battalion in Egypt.

The present contracts for the manufacture of the new short rifle are to be carried out, it is officially intimated, but there is a shrewd suspicion that no further contracts will be placed for the present. The weapon does not come up to the reputation claimed for it both on the ranges and in the knocking about incidental to camp life, and presumably active service. It will require some more tinkering, however, before it is finally cast aside. In the opinion of many experts the Lee-Enfield, with some little improvements, would be very much superior, and it has had the advantage of going through one campaign with good results.

One effect of Togo’s sensational wiping out of the Russian Fleet tell be the easing of the pockets of the hard-pressed British taxpayer. Russia was a presumptive foe to be reckoned with on the high seas, but Admiral Togo has solved that problem, and it is believed that the British Navy is now strong enough to meet any possible enemy and deal with it effectively. Consequently the shipbuilding programme is now open for revision. When the battleships now on the way home from China have joined the Mediterranean, Atlantic, and Channel Fleets, the naval strength in these waters will be enormously increased, especially in home waters.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT
New Issue of Shares for Increase of Capital
div.p: IN PURSUANCE of an Extraordinary Ge- neral Meeting held on the 18th May 1905, the Board of Directors of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt offer 248,000 new shares of the said Bank of Five punds sterling each. These shares will constitute an increase of Capital of the Bank, and are issued in conformity with the Statutes per share, payable on application.

Application should be made :-- in Egyot to the Head Office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo and to the Branch at Alexandria. in London to the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 &5, King William Street, E.C.
The new shares will rank for dividende from the 1st January 1906, that is to say from the beginning of next year.
Every shareholder has the right on applica- tion to an allotment of one new share in respect of every old share held.

All shareholders who wish to excercise their rights must, under pain of forfeiture of those rights, lodge their applications at one of the places named above on or before the 2nd October 1905 depositing their Share Warrants together with the total amount payable, viz : £ 5 per share.
The President of the Board of Directors, (signed) ELWIN PALMER
Cairo, the 8th July 1905.

Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
